results.name: a(n) is the denominator of r(n) where r(n) is the sequence of rational numbers defined by the recursion: r(0) = 0, r(1) = 1 and for n>1 r(n) = r(n-1) + r(n-2)/2. From this definition it is clear that a(n) is always a power of 2 (see A060755).
comment: It can be proved that r(n) is an integer (i.e. a(n) = 1) if and only if n is one of 0, 1, 2, 4, 8.
mathematica: Table[Denominator[Simplify[((1/2(1 + Sqrt[3]))^x - (1/2(Sqrt[3] - 1))^x Cos[Pi x])/ Sqrt[3]]], {x, 0, 43}]  (* _Peter Luschny_, Jun 02 2018 *)
